questions.prompt: When drawing the AC small-signal equivalent circuit, DC voltage sources become:
options: Resistors equal to their internal resistance
questions.explanation: A DC voltage source has zero AC impedance (it maintains a constant voltage regardless of current changes). In the small-signal model, VCC is shorted to ground because its AC voltage is zero — only the signal matters.

questions.prompt: Which h-parameter represents the input impedance of the transistor in the common-emitter model?
questions.explanation: hie is the input impedance (base-emitter resistance) measured at the transistor input with the output short-circuited for AC. For BC549, hie ≈ 2.7 kΩ and for BC556, hie ≈ 1.6 kΩ.

questions.prompt: The simplified voltage gain formula for this two-stage amplifier is:
questions.explanation: The simplified gain Av = hfe2 × R5 / R3 is derived by assuming R2 >> R3, ignoring hoe, and simplifying the interstage coupling. R3 is the gain-setting resistor — smaller R3 gives higher gain.

questions.prompt: For Av = 600, hfe2 = 220, and R5 = 220Ω, what value of R3 is needed?
questions.explanation: R3 = hfe2 × R5 / Av = 220 × 220 / 600 = 80.67 Ω. The nearest E12 value is 82 Ω. Choosing 68Ω would give Av ≈ 712, providing headroom for the loading effect of hie2.

questions.prompt: Why can we NOT ignore hie2 when calculating the actual gain?
options: Because hie2 (1.6kΩ) is comparable to R1 (1.8kΩ) — the ratio is only 1.1
Because hie2 is always dominant in any circuit
Because hie2 changes with temperature dramatically
Because hie2 is negative for PNP transistors
questions.correctAnswer: Because hie2 (1.6kΩ) is comparable to R1 (1.8kΩ) — the ratio is only 1.1
questions.explanation: The 10× rule requires R1/hie2 ≥ 10 for the approximation to be valid. Since R1/hie2 = 1800/1600 = 1.125, this ratio is far below 10, so hie2 significantly loads stage 1 and reduces the actual gain below the simplified formula.

questions.prompt: What is the output impedance of the amplifier approximately equal to?
questions.explanation: Looking back from the output, Zout = R5 ∥ (1/hoe2) ≈ R5 since 1/hoe2 = 56kΩ >> R5 = 220Ω. The output impedance is dominated by R5, the emitter resistor of the PNP stage.

questions.prompt: In the AC equivalent, coupling capacitors are treated as:
questions.explanation: At the signal frequency (typically 1 kHz), the capacitor impedance 1/(2πfC) is designed to be much smaller than surrounding resistors. They pass AC signals freely and are treated as short circuits in the small-signal model.

questions.prompt: The input impedance of the amplifier is determined by:
questions.explanation: The voltage divider (Ra, Rb) and the transistor input impedance [hie1 + (1+hfe1)R3] are all in parallel from the signal source's perspective. The smallest component dominates the parallel combination.

questions.prompt: Why does the professor recommend choosing R3 = 68Ω instead of 82Ω?
options: 68Ω is a more common value in the lab
To compensate for gain loss due to hie2 loading — 68Ω gives Av ≈ 712 instead of 590
questions.correctAnswer: To compensate for gain loss due to hie2 loading — 68Ω gives Av ≈ 712 instead of 590
questions.explanation: The simplified formula gives Av = 590 with R3 = 82Ω, but the actual gain is lower due to hie2 loading. Choosing R3 = 68Ω sets a theoretical Av ≈ 712, providing headroom so the actual gain (after losses) is closer to the target of 600.

questions.prompt: hoe = 18μS for the BC549. Why can we ignore it in this design?
options: Because it makes the math easier
Because 1/hoe = 56kΩ, which is over 250× larger than R5 = 220Ω — well above the 10× threshold
Because hoe only matters at very high frequencies
Because hoe cancels out between the two stages
questions.correctAnswer: Because 1/hoe = 56kΩ, which is over 250× larger than R5 = 220Ω — well above the 10× threshold
questions.explanation: The 10× rule: if one parallel resistor is 10× larger than the other, the parallel combination is within 10% of the smaller. Since 1/hoe ≈ 56kΩ >> R5 = 220Ω (ratio 254), the output conductance hoe has negligible effect.
